ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: historiography, extensive reading, reformation history and theology
Improved knowledge of Luther's life and ideology; examined from a number of angles.
Useful combination of historical and theological insight on an often misunderstood man, helpful thematic focus
It provided an excellent context for the Protestant Reformation in that the instructors often wove into their lectures some of the social and political dynamics.
The class allowed me to re-read and refresh my knowledge of Luther's canon as well as catch up on the recent historiography surrounding the German reformer.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The strengths are in the fact that it is based on primary sources. It was a rich experience actually reading the documents and not simply reading secondary literature. I honestly can't think of any weaknesses.

The ability to draw upon the knowledge of both Gordon and Eire during class discussions was definitely a strength of the course. My only critique would be that the class size was a bit large, but this was alleviated by splitting it up for discussions of primary material.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, absolutely - Bruce Gordon and Carlos Eire are wonderful, and I learned so much from them
Absolutely, though the seminar might function better with less students
I would definitely recommend this class to another student, both for the importance of Luther and for the ability to take a class with Gordon and Eire at the same time.
